1. thin-sectioned & filled (Shotton). "material is fine acid ash with tiny cubes of pyrites, probly a volcanic rock that has suffered subsequent thermal metamorphism. In general terms it would go into the (BA Petrology Group VII, much of which is derived from North Pembrokeshire, but in this case Professor Shotton would not be prepared to go beyond the probability that the source is Welsh." Dr. H.N. Savory on Prof. Shotton's report.'
2. found in a field behind farmhouse.

1. Flint. 7(8) or 10
2. faces are fresh + look unpatinated, but all edges seem to be worn. Side + poll edges could have been ground, but if so, this is obscured by wear. 
3. grinding on back face is more extensive than on front. This is because a large flat facet (cleavage surface of rock, or flat scar facet) has been ground lightly.
4. Arch. Camb. 6, 1926, 199-200 Fig. shows front face. Found 'near a tree stamp of the ancient forest bed'.

1. Cae. 18
2. back face is weathered & damaged, obscuring details of grinding. It rather looks as if left side was not ground, but this is not clear. LEFEDWID + GRINSIDE are given for right side edge, which is better preserved.

info.comments: 1. Sliced. P44: a gritty tuff, undoubtedly of local origin, & resembling several gritty tuffs from the St Davids Head area, in particular 2 slides in the Geol. Survey Collection from Ramsey Island.
info.labels:
Stone axe from Clegyr Voia, St. Daods, mentioned in the Rev. S. Barivey-Gould's report on excavations made in 1902. See Archaeologia Cambrensis 1903 p.6 A71
(P44)

info.comments:
1. DEN. 6
2. grinding on back faces concentrated at top of right side, as on front, but less extensive. The ground faces meet at a pointed edge.
3. stone is weathered & worn, so that extent of grinding is somewhat obscured. This is so especially on edges: most of left side edge is worn away, so it could have been more ground than 55, & poll edge is completely missing.
4. Ellis Davies, 1939, The Prehistoric & Roman remains of Denbighshire, Cardiff, WM. Lewis Ltd. In Caernanon Free Library, 1920, 2 axes exhibited, "found at Llwyn Ynn", inc. this one (Fig. 64 A). By process of correct logic, Davies decides that the other one is that referred to in a note in library, which describes an axe from Coed Cochion wood (Llwyn Ynn) (pp 216-8). 'Caeau Cochion, near Ruthin' is on NMW card, presumably communicated by Caernanon Town Council who gave celts to NMW. This information was clearly not available to Davies, & should perhaps be doubted.

info.comments:
1. N. 30 (80012) + N.73 (88013 ), both described in petrology report as VIII, are macroscopically very different. N.30 is a homogeneous looking grey stone, apparently worked by flaking. N.73 is grey with fine darker mottling throughout, & seems to have been shaped by pecking. Where heavily ground, N.73 is smooth-surfaced: this is especially so on blade, & to a less extent on + around side & poll edges. Elsewhere, the pecked surface shows through + overall the stone lacks the sine of the fully ground parts of N.73, or the whole surface N.30. The only macroscopic similarly lies in the 'marble-like' surface of the unground stone. 
2. N.73
info.labels:

DEOPHAM, per Mr B JOHNSON
